Empires & Puzzles Alfie Review: 4-Star Nature Hero Guide

Alfie brings the Super Elemental chaos to the 4-star arena. With a fiddle in hand and a grin that's slightly unsettling, he plays a symphony of ailments that targets enemies based on their element. Is he a budget Jequn or just a court fool? We break down his stats and skills.
Alfie: The Jester Who Debuffs The Entire Rainbow
Alfie is a 4-star Nature (Green) hero from the

family, released back in August 2023. He fills the role of a disruptive support attacker, acting essentially as a "lite" version of the 5-star hero Jequn. While Jequn zips around at Very Fast speed, Alfie takes his time at

speed, playing a more measured tune. He is designed to punish rainbow defenses by handing out specific ailments to Ice, Holy, Dark, and Fire enemies. If you've ever wanted a hero who brings a unique gift for everyone at the party (even if it's a terrible gift like lowered accuracy), Alfie is your guy.

Visually, Alfie is... distinct. He’s a full-blown court jester clad in varying shades of green, complete with a harlequin cap and a violin that looks like it's seen better days. His expression is manic, bordering on "I might burn the castle down for a laugh." Compared to the stoic warriors and majestic beasts usually found in Nature, Alfie looks like he wandered in from a twisted carnival. The "Enchanted Symphony" theme fits perfectly with his pose, though one has to wonder if the music he plays is actually melodious or just screeching cats.
Alfie’s stats show his age. With a base Power of
, he sits significantly behind modern 4-star marvels like
(Power 795) or the latest Costume Quest releases. His Attack of

are quite modest by today's standards, where we regularly see 4-stars pushing 800+ in base stats. He is visibly squishier than the current generation of heroes, meaning he relies heavily on his Limit Breaks and Emblems to survive long enough to fire his Average speed skill.
Alfie’s special skill is a "Jack of all trades" debuff package. He deals
, which is a decent slap but won't wipe teams on its own. The real meat of the skill is the elemental hate:
-30% Accuracy. This is his strongest ailment (Blind), effectively neutralizing dangerous Blue hitters.
-30% Mana Generation. Excellent for slowing down those pesky Yellow healers or snipers.
-30% Defense. A solid setup for your other hitters.
-30% Attack. Helps mitigate damage from the color that is strong against him.
The versatility is great, but the
speed is a hindrance. In a standard raid, waiting for 10 tiles to apply these debuffs can feel like an eternity. However, in
formats, this skill becomes incredibly oppressive, blanketing the enemy team in a variety of debilitating effects before they can get going.
to charge. With a Level 23 Mana Troop (or a combination of talents/costume bonuses/bards), you can drop this to 9 tiles, making him much more consistent.
At roughly 705 Attack, a 200% hit deals approximately
total across a team of 5 (before defense calculations). This is "softening" damage, not "finishing" damage.
passive is huge. Against Ice enemies (his weak target), his troops deal
. This makes his tile damage against Titans or Blue tanks surprisingly potent, often hitting harder than his stats suggest.
Family Bonus, Passives, Aether Power & Unique Abilities
The Super Elemental family brings unique mechanics that elevate Alfie’s utility beyond his special skill.
mechanic is fantastic. Every few turns, Alfie generates a Power Gem that deals random damage. When matched, these gems deal damage to
. This adds a layer of passive damage that accumulates over time, and since it’s board-based, it works even if Alfie is silenced (provided the gems are already there).
+100% elemental damage vs. Ice. This makes him a tile-damage monster against Blue Titans or Mythic Titans.
-10% damage received from Fire. A nice little survival boost against his counter-element, though likely not enough to save him from a modern Red sniper.
gives him a raw stat boost at the start of the battle. While simple, it helps his tile damage and special skill punch slightly above his weight class for the first few turns.
Upon release, Alfie was seen as a "Mini-Jequn" and a solid option for players who missed out on the 5-star Super Elementals. He was appreciated for bringing a complex mechanic to the 4-star rarity.
The game has accelerated rapidly. New 4-star heroes from the
families often boast stats that rival older 5-stars. Alfie's 688 Power is low. His 200% hit at Average speed is largely outclassed by heroes like
(300% to 3 at Average with huge burns) or
Alfie has moved from a general-use hero to a
. He is still very viable in
where his speed is fixed, and his wide array of ailments can cripple a team. He also retains value against
due to his Power Gems and Troop Mastery passive boosting tile damage significantly. Outside of these scenarios, he is hard to justify over faster, harder-hitting modern 4-stars.
Since Alfie is already statistically behind, you have two distinct choices depending on how you use him.
Keeps him alive long enough to cast his skill. His base defense is low, so he needs every point of bulk he can get to survive modern snipers.
His special skill damage becomes negligible, turning him purely into a debuffer/tile bot.
passive for Titan hits and stack damage. Makes his Power Gems hit harder.
He becomes very fragile and might die before firing his special in raids.
path is safer for PvP use. However, if you primarily use him for
Can apply Blind, Mana Slow, Defense Down, and Attack Down all in one cast depending on the enemy composition.
Provides free, passive damage to all enemies when gems are matched.
Troop Mastery passive (+100% damage vs Ice) makes his tiles hit incredibly hard against Blue targets.
At Very Fast speed, his skill is devastatingly disruptive.
His bulk and attack power are significantly lower than 2024/2025 4-star releases.
Too slow for the impact he provides in standard speed formats.
If the enemy team is mono-Nature, his specific elemental debuffs do nothing (he only deals damage).
200% damage is essentially a "tickle" to modern overhealed teams.
This is his playground. He can fire early and mess up the enemy's tempo with mana cuts and blinds.
His passive boosts tile damage immensely, and Power Gems add extra hits.
While he doesn't buff, his ailments prevent enemies from buffing effectively if they are Holy (Mana slow) or Ice (Blind).
Alfie works best when you lean into his chaos or use him to set up stronger hitters.
A flurry of hits to all enemies, silence, mana control, and increased damage taken.
Alfie is there for the tile damage boost and Power Gems, while the others provide the buffs and debuffs.
(like Rigard or C. Caedmon) completely nullify his special skill's after-effects.
Avoid pairing him with heroes who overwrite his specific debuffs with weaker versions, though his are quite specific so this is rare.

Alfie is a great catch for a developing roster. His ability to handle multiple threats makes him a "Swiss Army Knife" for early map stages and raids. Don't worry too much about his speed early on; his utility is worth the wait.
Alfie is likely a benchwarmer for your main war teams unless it's
. However, do not feed him away if you care about high Titan scores. His
passive is unique and valuable for pushing damage on Blue Titans without needing 5-star items. He does not need Alpha Aethers (LB2) unless you are extremely competitive in 4-star tournaments.
The community reaction to Alfie was mixed but generally positive regarding his design.
Jequn. Hoping he won’t get nerfed before release."*
Others were skeptical of the speed:
"I believe him being average speed really hurt his usability... A disruptive skill like this needs to be v fast or at least fast."
"Alfie’s son. And the father is Derric."
The general consensus has settled on him being a
hero—a dirty word in a meta that favors the Overpowered. As one player put it:
that puts green shields on your board... I must be the only person who likes this hero."*

Alfie is the definition of a "fun" hero who unfortunately lives in a "serious" world of power creep. He brings a chaotic, flavorful kit that can single-handedly dismantle a rainbow defense in Rush wars, but his average speed and aging stats hold him back from being a daily driver. He's not the king of the court, but he's certainly the most entertaining jester we have.
Keep for Rush Tournaments and Blue Titans.
